job_title: Lecturer in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros:
Pay and benefits are competitive. 

The director of my department acts strict, but it's all a show. After a while, nobody really checks up on you.
cons:
It takes the worst elements of a Japanese hierarchical organization, and combines them with a cult of personality. Upper admin are all conservative Japanese men who require you to make curricula that adhere to the Japanese definition of a "good education." This means that all the needs analysis data and research based arguments for my curriculum went out the window, in favor of having the students engage in rote memorization and busy work, to take arbitrarily-made paper exams.

Tributes to the school's founder, a Japanese billionaire and cult leader, are everywhere. The students all claim they admire him deeply, and your coworkers will agree. Faculty/staff events (such as reading circles) revolve around reading the founder's books.

The school officially pushes its image of a "secular institution", except the organization they are distancing themselves from is the school's major financier, and leaders of that same organization are the decision-makers on campus. 

The students are almost all from the organization's feeder schools, starting from kindergarten, all the way up from university. It's really sad to see.

job_title: in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: Soka University has a stunningly beautiful campus and has a wonderful culture of caring for the individual.  It's really a joy to work here because of the people who work here and the students who attend this campus from 23 states and over 40 countries.  The benefits are very good and the university has not laid off any employees during the difficult economy we've experienced the last few years.  The Soka Bistro is a great place to have  lunch and the cost for all you can eat is just $5.25 for employees.  We also have free parking, free access to most events on campus -- and free tuition for our children if they are admitted.
cons: Because Soka University is a private, non-profit liberal arts college, salaries are comparable to similar colleges -- but cannot compete with corporate salaries. It's also hard to get to know all of the students because our office is not in the academic core.

review_title: High faculty turnover due to a subculture of a Soka Gakkai religious elite; a sectarian college
job_title: Professor/Faculty in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: Students are quite focused on learning and not distracted by either intercollegiate sports or binge drinking. Facilities are quite new. Soka Bistro's food is excellent.
cons: Non-Soka Gakkai (SGI) believers are shut out of believers' meetings where the most important decisions are made behind closed doors; it's sort of like a small theocracy or communist party ruled regime. University President more likely to eulogize SGI Great Leader Ikeda than to discuss issues of academic significance. Curriculum is very rigid with fewer electives for students to choose from. Students are required to live in on-campus dorms all 4 years: infantilization. A large proportion of students come from feeder SGI high schools, many in Japan; certain ideas such as doubts about the SGI doctrine are verboten.

job_title: Tour Guide in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: My bosses have always been friendly, and the people I work with are easy to get along with. So far, I have enjoyed giving tours to people, as there is a wide range of people to see. I also work reception, so that's a job that's fairly easy, and it helps me learn more about the campus I work on. The people that trained me explained things easily so I could understand what they expect from me, rather than me having to guess at what I'm supposed to do. It seems like the atmosphere here is not too strict since people like to converse while in the office, which is nice because then it ensures that things don't feel too formal or stuffy. It's easy to ask for help and go up to others to say hi. For what I do, the pay is fair.
cons: Sometimes days can be a little slow when it comes to tours, but I'm always around people that have tasks and are willing to help!

review_title: A school that practices what it preaches
job_title: Tour Guide in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros:
I am currently a student in Soka University of America's MA program in Educational Leadership and Societal Change; students in this program work to develop the skills they will need to overcome the challenges facing society in the 21st century.  At the same time, I work for the school's Community Relations office as a student tour guide.  My experience working for the school has shown me that the professional work environment at this school is as exceptional as the quality of its academics.

The word 'Soka' means value-creation in Japanese, and every aspect of this schools design and day-to-day operations are meant to create value in the lives of its students, staff, and faculty.  At Soka, students can work at almost all campus departments except security and facilities.  This provides plenty of opportunity for students to gain experience and supplement their already generous financial aid.  Soka goes to great lengths to ensure that every student is able to obtain a world-class education, and in fact, students whose families earn less than $60,000 per year have their tuition waived.  Because the school is very small—with just over 450 undergraduates—the campus community is tight-knit.  Students get to know their professors very well over the four years they spend here, which is great when it comes time to apply for internships, jobs, or graduate school.  Classes are small as well, with usually just 12 students in any given class section, and are typically arranged so that instruction occurs along the lines of a Socratic seminar, in which students and teacher all participate together in classroom discussion.

Students at Soka are always encouraged to be active participants in the process of learning, and to take charge of their scholarly and personal lives.  In terms of residential life, the residence halls are well-equipped (free laundry!) and students never have to share their room with more than one other person—incoming first-year students live in double rooms with a private bathroom, while returning students live in suites with two private bedrooms and a bathroom per suite.  Meals are included in room and board, which helps put all students on an equal footing.  There's also a shuttle service that takes students to the Aliso Viejo town center and nearby locations on the half hour.

Overall, I can wholeheartedly recommend Soka University of America as a school that has devoted all its resources toward realizing its mission statement, which is "to foster a steady stream of global citizens omitted to living a contributive life."  At many other schools, the mission might just be an abstract ideal not palpable in the daily routine, but at Soka, every member of the campus community works to make this mission a reality.
cons:
The city in which Soka University of America is located, Aliso Viejo, California, is a rather quiet and suburban area, which means that there is relatively little to do off-campus within a close distance to the school.  Although there is a shuttle service, going to places such as Los Angeles requires a car or the use of public transportation, the latter of which is a bit inconvenient in Southern California.  Luckily there's a lot of fun activities to do on-campus, such as student clubs and organizations, as well as service projects.  Still, because Soka is such a small school, it can sometimes feel a bit boring or isolated, especially during break periods and holidays, when some students travel or visit home.

Although the school's small size makes it easy for student voices to be heard, sometimes, there simply aren't enough students facing a certain challenge or situation for there to be a 'critical mass' which means that sometimes, specific and unusual circumstances may take a little while to be addressed.  Moreover, depending on the concentration a student is trying to pursue at Soka, they may find some of the class offerings a bit restrictive.  This is being addressed in part by the new Life Sciences concentration that opens Fall 2020.

Still, despite a few drawbacks, it's clear that Soka makes every effort to address the needs of its students as promptly as possible.  Again, at least for me, working for Soka as a student employee has been an invaluable experience that would not have been possible anywhere else.

review_title: A great new university and a great place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: Soka University staff and faculty receive great benefits (full medical,dental and vision coverage for yourself and dependents), contributions to a retirement plan and free use of recreation and fitness facilities...along with free parking and a 50% discount at the dining hall.  The college is in a beautiful location about one mile from the Pacific Ocean (if you're a bird. 7 miles by car.)
cons: It's a small college (450 students) so there aren't a lot of career pathways.  Some offices have no where to "grow".

review_title: Soka Performing Arts Center - Student Employment
job_title: Performing Arts Center, Student Employee in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: The culture of care is prominent amongst employees and departments at the Soka Performing Arts Center. It is absolutely the best on-campus employer in terms of practical work experiences and opportunities to grow and build your resume. It has definitely been an unbeatable experience.
cons: I suppose it is more demanding in terms of commitment than other on-campus jobs, however, management is very flexible and understanding of students' other responsibilities.
